categories.name: Metaphysics
categories.description: Being, existence, causation, and the fundamental structure of reality

categories.name: Epistemology
categories.description: Knowledge, truth, and the powers and limits of human reason

categories.name: Logic
categories.description: Principles of valid reasoning, logical demonstration, and rational inference

categories.name: Theology
categories.description: Rational study of God, divine attributes, and religious truth

categories.name: Philosophy
categories.description: General philosophical arguments including naturalistic and skeptical positions

categories.name: Ethics
categories.description: Moral principles, natural law, and the human good

categories.name: Philosophical Anthropology
categories.description: Human nature, the soul, personal identity, and human destiny

axioms.title: Something exists
axioms.description: At minimum, I exist as a thinking being. This is self-evident and cannot be coherently denied.

axioms.title: Principle of non-contradiction
axioms.description: Something cannot both be and not be in the same respect at the same time. Contradictory statements cannot both be true.

axioms.title: Senses provide knowledge of reality
axioms.description: Our senses, though sometimes mistaken, generally provide reliable information about the external world.

axioms.title: Principle of causation
axioms.description: Every effect has a cause. Nothing comes into being without a sufficient reason for its existence.

axioms.title: Change and motion occur
axioms.description: We observe that things change, move, and are actualized from potency to act. This is evident to our senses.

axioms.title: Distinction between contingent and necessary existence
axioms.description: Some things exist but could have not existed (contingent), while other things, if they exist, must exist (necessary).

axioms.title: Degrees of perfection exist
axioms.description: We observe that some things are more perfect, good, true, or noble than others. There are degrees of excellence.

axioms.title: Things are ordered toward ends
axioms.description: Natural things appear to act for specific purposes or ends, even when they lack intelligence to direct themselves.

axioms.title: Human reason can discover truth
axioms.description: Through careful reasoning and logic, humans can attain genuine knowledge about reality, including metaphysical truths.

arguments.title: An external world exists
arguments.description: Given that our senses are generally reliable and we observe consistent patterns, there exists a world of material objects external to our minds.
arguments.conclusion: Material reality exists independently of our consciousness

arguments.title: Causal series exist in nature
arguments.description: Since change occurs and every effect has a cause, there exist chains of causation connecting events in the natural world.
arguments.conclusion: Reality is structured by causal relationships

arguments.title: Distinction between actual and potential
arguments.description: Since change occurs, there must be a real distinction between what something actually is and what it potentially could become.
arguments.conclusion: Actuality and potentiality are fundamental aspects of reality

arguments.title: Hierarchy of being exists
arguments.description: Given degrees of perfection and the reliability of our rational judgments, there exists a real hierarchy in the order of being.
arguments.conclusion: Some beings are more perfect or excellent than others

arguments.title: Natural processes are teleologically ordered
arguments.description: Since things are ordered toward ends and our reason can discern this order, natural processes exhibit genuine purposiveness.
arguments.conclusion: Nature displays inherent purposiveness and order

arguments.title: Contingent beings exist
arguments.description: Using the distinction between contingent and necessary existence, and observing material things that come into being and pass away, we can identify contingent beings.
arguments.conclusion: Some beings exist but could have not existed

arguments.title: Rational knowledge of reality is possible
arguments.description: Since reason can discover truth and we can distinguish real from apparent contradictions, genuine metaphysical knowledge is attainable.
arguments.conclusion: Human reason can know the fundamental structure of reality

arguments.title: Efficient causation operates in nature
arguments.description: Given that causal series exist and we can observe agents producing effects, efficient causation is a real principle governing natural processes.
arguments.conclusion: Agents actively cause effects in the natural world

arguments.title: Infinite regress in essential causation is impossible
arguments.description: If causal series exist and efficient causation operates, an infinite regress of essential causes is metaphysically impossible - there must be a first cause.
arguments.conclusion: Essential causal series require a first uncaused cause

arguments.title: A Prime Mover is necessary
arguments.description: Given that change occurs, actual vs potential distinction exists, and infinite regress is impossible, there must be a first unmoved mover.
arguments.conclusion: There exists a first principle of motion that is itself unmoved

arguments.title: A necessary being exists
arguments.description: Since contingent beings exist and infinite regress is impossible, there must exist at least one being that exists necessarily.
arguments.conclusion: There exists a being whose essence involves existence

arguments.title: A supremely perfect being exists
arguments.description: Given the hierarchy of being and degrees of perfection, there must be a most perfect being that serves as the standard for all degrees of goodness.
arguments.conclusion: There exists a being of maximum perfection

arguments.title: An intelligent designer exists
arguments.description: Since natural teleology exists and things lacking intelligence cannot direct themselves toward ends, there must be an intelligent cause ordering nature.
arguments.conclusion: There exists an intelligence that orders natural processes toward their ends

arguments.title: Material causes alone are insufficient
arguments.description: Given that rational knowledge is possible and we observe formal structure, final causation, and efficient agency, purely material explanations are inadequate.
arguments.conclusion: Reality requires non-material principles of explanation

arguments.title: First principles converge in unity
arguments.description: Since rational knowledge is possible and we have identified multiple first principles (Prime Mover, First Cause, Necessary Being, etc.), reason suggests these converge in one supreme principle.
arguments.conclusion: The various first principles are unified in one supreme being

arguments.title: Contingent existence requires explanation
arguments.description: Since contingent beings exist and the principle of sufficient reason applies, the existence of contingent reality as a whole requires explanation by something non-contingent.
arguments.conclusion: The totality of contingent existence requires a necessary ground

arguments.title: God exists as the First Mover (First Way)
arguments.description: Since a Prime Mover is necessary and first principles converge in unity, this unmoved mover is what we call God - pure actuality without potency.
arguments.conclusion: God exists as the pure actualized being who moves all things

arguments.title: God exists as the First Efficient Cause (Second Way)
arguments.description: Since infinite regress is impossible and unity of first principles holds, the uncaused first cause is God - the source of all efficient causation.
arguments.conclusion: God exists as the first uncaused cause of all effects

arguments.title: God exists as the Necessary Being (Third Way)
arguments.description: Since a necessary being exists and first principles converge, this necessary being whose essence is existence is God.
arguments.conclusion: God exists as the being whose very essence is to exist

arguments.title: God exists as the Most Perfect Being (Fourth Way)
arguments.description: Since a supremely perfect being exists and first principles converge, this most perfect being is God - the source of all goodness and truth.
arguments.conclusion: God exists as the most perfect being and source of all perfection

arguments.title: God exists as the Intelligent Governor (Fifth Way)
arguments.description: Since an intelligent designer exists and first principles converge, this supreme intelligence governing natural order is God.
arguments.conclusion: God exists as the supreme intelligence governing all natural processes

arguments.title: Naturalism provides sufficient explanation
arguments.description: If material causes and natural processes can account for observed phenomena without invoking non-material principles, then naturalistic explanations are sufficient.
arguments.conclusion: Natural processes alone can explain reality without supernatural intervention

arguments.title: Infinite regress may be metaphysically permissible
arguments.description: If our understanding of causation and infinity is limited, infinite causal chains might not be logically impossible, eliminating the need for a first cause.
arguments.conclusion: Infinite causal series are metaphysically possible

arguments.title: The existence of evil disproves a perfect God
arguments.description: If we observe suffering and evil in the world, and a perfect God would prevent gratuitous evil, then a perfectly good and omnipotent God does not exist.
arguments.conclusion: The reality of evil is incompatible with God's existence

arguments.title: Apparent design explained by natural selection
arguments.description: If natural processes like evolution can account for apparent teleological order without intelligent design, then an intelligent designer is unnecessary.
arguments.conclusion: Apparent design in nature results from natural processes, not intelligence

arguments.title: Contingent existence may require no explanation
arguments.description: If the principle of sufficient reason is not universally valid, or if existence itself is a brute fact, then contingent reality need not require explanation by a necessary being.
arguments.conclusion: Contingent existence can be accepted as a brute fact without explanation

arguments.title: Divine providence governs the universe
arguments.description: If God exists as the intelligent governor and perfect being, then divine providence directs all events toward their proper ends according to divine wisdom.
arguments.conclusion: All events are ultimately ordered by divine providence toward good ends

arguments.title: Natural law derives from eternal law
arguments.description: If God exists as the intelligent governor and natural teleology is real, then moral principles accessible to human reason derive from God's eternal law.
arguments.conclusion: Objective moral law has its foundation in divine eternal law

arguments.title: The human soul is immortal
arguments.description: If God exists as perfect being and humans have rational capacities transcending material processes, then the human soul, being spiritual, is naturally immortal.
arguments.conclusion: Human souls survive bodily death and are naturally immortal

arguments.title: Human life has ultimate purpose
arguments.description: If God exists as the intelligent governor and natural teleology is real, then human existence is directed toward union with God as its ultimate end.
arguments.conclusion: Human life finds its ultimate purpose in relationship with God

arguments.title: God permits evil for greater good
arguments.description: If God exists as perfect being and divine providence governs, then evil is permitted only insofar as it serves some greater good that could not otherwise be achieved.
arguments.conclusion: All evil permitted by God ultimately serves a greater good

arguments.title: Reality is purely material
arguments.description: If naturalism is sufficient and design appears naturally explained, then reality consists entirely of material substances governed by natural laws without supernatural elements.
arguments.conclusion: The universe is entirely material with no spiritual or supernatural reality

arguments.title: Human existence has no ultimate purpose
arguments.description: If reality is purely material and contingent existence requires no explanation, then human life has no inherent purpose beyond what humans create for themselves.
arguments.conclusion: Human existence has no objective ultimate purpose or meaning

arguments.title: Morality is socially constructed
arguments.description: If reality is purely material and no ultimate purpose exists, then moral principles are human constructions rather than objective features of reality.
arguments.conclusion: Moral values are social conventions without objective foundation

arguments.title: Consciousness is reducible to brain states
arguments.description: If reality is purely material and naturalism is sufficient, then consciousness and mental phenomena are entirely reducible to physical brain processes.
arguments.conclusion: Consciousness has no independent reality beyond material brain states

arguments.title: Death is the final end of personal existence
arguments.description: If consciousness is reducible to brain states and reality is purely material, then personal existence ends completely with biological death.
arguments.conclusion: There is no survival of personal identity after death

arguments.title: Ultimate metaphysical questions are unanswerable
arguments.description: If both theistic and atheistic arguments have significant weaknesses, and human reason has limitations, then ultimate questions about God's existence may be beyond human knowledge.
arguments.conclusion: We cannot know with certainty whether God exists or not

relation.description: Existence of self supports external world reality
Principle of causation implies causal series in nature
Observed change implies act/potency distinction
Degrees of perfection establish hierarchy of being
Teleological order implies natural purposiveness
Efficient causation supports impossibility of infinite regress
Act/potency distinction supports need for Prime Mover
Contingent beings imply necessary being
Hierarchy of being implies supreme perfection
Natural teleology implies intelligent designer
Prime Mover argument leads to God (First Way)
First Cause argument leads to God (Second Way)
Necessary Being argument leads to God (Third Way)
Supreme Perfection argument leads to God (Fourth Way)
Intelligent Design argument leads to God (Fifth Way)
Naturalism contradicts need for immaterial explanation
Permissible infinite regress contradicts impossibility
Problem of evil contradicts perfect God
Natural design explanation contradicts intelligent designer
God as governor implies divine providence
Perfect God implies natural law foundation
Perfect God supports human soul immortality
Divine providence implies theodicy response to evil
Sufficient naturalism implies pure materialism
Pure materialism implies no ultimate purpose
Pure materialism implies consciousness reduction
Consciousness reduction implies finality of death
Soul immortality contradicts final death
Natural law contradicts social construction of morality
Ultimate purpose contradicts meaninglessness

sources.name: Immanuel Kant
key_works: Groundwork of the Metaphysics of Morals

sources.name: Empiricism
sources.description: Knowledge comes primarily from sensory experience

sources.name: Rationalism
sources.description: Reason is the primary source of knowledge

sources.name: Utilitarianism
sources.description: Actions are right if they produce the greatest good for the greatest number

sources.name: Deontological Ethics
sources.description: Ethics based on duty and rules rather than consequences

sources.name: Virtue Ethics
sources.description: Ethics based on character traits and virtues

sources.name: Social Contract Theory
sources.description: Political authority derives from agreements among people

sources.name: Natural Law Theory
sources.description: Universal moral principles discoverable by reason

sources.name: Existentialism
sources.description: Existence precedes essence; emphasis on individual experience

sources.name: Philosophical Materialism
sources.description: Reality consists only of matter and energy

sources.name: Philosophical Idealism
sources.description: Reality is fundamentally mental or spiritual
